title: Bank of China provides $260 million buyer's credit loan for 440MW Mao Khe Coal-Fired Power Plant Construction Project (Linked to Project ID#73296)
description: On April 7, 2011, the Hubei Branch of the Bank of China (BOC) and BNP Paribas (a French banking group) signed a $275 million syndicated buyer’s credit loan agreement with Vietnam National Coal, Mineral Industries Corporation (Vinacomin) — a Vietnamese state-owned enterprise — for the 440MW Mao Khe Coal-Fired Power Plant Construction Project. BOC contributed $260 million to the syndicated loan (captured via Project ID#65937). The loan carries a 13-year maturity, but its interest rate and grace period are unknown. The Vietnamese Ministry of Finance provided a sovereign guarantee for the loan and Sinosure provided buyer’s credit insurance.   Then, on February 25, 2012, the Export-Import Bank of China issued a buyer’s credit loan worth approximately RMB 200 million for the same project (captured via Project #73296). This loan reportedly carried a maturity of 3 years and an interest rate of 3.51%. Sinosure also provided buyer’s credit insurance for this loan. The Export-Import Bank of Vietnam also provided a $56 million loan — with a 13-year maturity, 3-year grace period, and 4.5-4.8% interest rate — for the project. The proceeds from these three loans were used to partially finance a $429.5 million EPC contract between Vinacomin and China’s KAIDI Electric Power Co. Ltd. signed on July 7, 2009. The total project investment equal to $577 million was financed by 20% equity and 80% debt.   The purpose of the project was to construct a 440MW coali-fired power plant — with two, 220MW power generation units (Unit 1 and Unit 2) — that uses circulating fluidized-bed technology in Bình Khê commune, Đông Triều district, Quảng Ninh province. KAIDI Electric Power Co. was the main EPC contractor but Wuhan KAIDI Electric Power Engineering Company and WULFF (a German firm) helped implement the project. Construction commenced on July 8, 2009.  Unit 1 became operational in October 2012, and Unit 2 became operational in January 2013. On April 12, 2013, the project was officially completed.   Since the plant started operating, residents in nearby Đông Sơn and Xuân Bình hamlets say that their lives have been negatively affected by the plant's operations. Vu Thanh An, the Party secretary of Đông Sơn, said that the plant had begun dumping pollutants into the Cấm River within days of beginning operations. Le Ba Cai, a resident of Đông Sơn who lives only 500 meters from the plant, said that strong shaking from the plant's operations had cracked the walls of his house. Another resident, Ngo Thi Nhi, said coal dust covered her house every day, and that she heard loud explosions each night.
staff_comments: 1. This project is also known as the 2x220 MW Mao Khe 1 and 2 coal-fired power plants and the 440MW Mao Khe Thermoelectric Power Plant Project. The Chinese project title is 凯迪电力越南冒溪热电厂. The Vietnamese project title is Dự án Nhiệt điện Mạo Khê or Dự án NMNĐ Mạo Khê.2. The China Eximbank loan that supported this project is not included in the Overseas Development Finance Dataset that Boston University’s Global Development Policy Center published in December 2020.
combined_text:
# Sector
ENERGY

# Title
Bank of China provides $260 million buyer's credit loan for 440MW Mao Khe Coal-Fired Power Plant Construction Project (Linked to Project ID#73296)

# Description
On April 7, 2011, the Hubei Branch of the Bank of China (BOC) and BNP Paribas (a French banking group) signed a $275 million syndicated buyer’s credit loan agreement with Vietnam National Coal, Mineral Industries Corporation (Vinacomin) — a Vietnamese state-owned enterprise — for the 440MW Mao Khe Coal-Fired Power Plant Construction Project. BOC contributed $260 million to the syndicated loan (captured via Project ID#65937). The loan carries a 13-year maturity, but its interest rate and grace period are unknown. The Vietnamese Ministry of Finance provided a sovereign guarantee for the loan and Sinosure provided buyer’s credit insurance.   Then, on February 25, 2012, the Export-Import Bank of China issued a buyer’s credit loan worth approximately RMB 200 million for the same project (captured via Project #73296). This loan reportedly carried a maturity of 3 years and an interest rate of 3.51%. Sinosure also provided buyer’s credit insurance for this loan. The Export-Import Bank of Vietnam also provided a $56 million loan — with a 13-year maturity, 3-year grace period, and 4.5-4.8% interest rate — for the project. The proceeds from these three loans were used to partially finance a $429.5 million EPC contract between Vinacomin and China’s KAIDI Electric Power Co. Ltd. signed on July 7, 2009. The total project investment equal to $577 million was financed by 20% equity and 80% debt.   The purpose of the project was to construct a 440MW coali-fired power plant — with two, 220MW power generation units (Unit 1 and Unit 2) — that uses circulating fluidized-bed technology in Bình Khê commune, Đông Triều district, Quảng Ninh province. KAIDI Electric Power Co. was the main EPC contractor but Wuhan KAIDI Electric Power Engineering Company and WULFF (a German firm) helped implement the project. Construction commenced on July 8, 2009.  Unit 1 became operational in October 2012, and Unit 2 became operational in January 2013. On April 12, 2013, the project was officially completed.   Since the plant started operating, residents in nearby Đông Sơn and Xuân Bình hamlets say that their lives have been negatively affected by the plant's operations. Vu Thanh An, the Party secretary of Đông Sơn, said that the plant had begun dumping pollutants into the Cấm River within days of beginning operations. Le Ba Cai, a resident of Đông Sơn who lives only 500 meters from the plant, said that strong shaking from the plant's operations had cracked the walls of his house. Another resident, Ngo Thi Nhi, said coal dust covered her house every day, and that she heard loud explosions each night.
justification: Primary purpose is coal-fired power generation, which is environmentally harmful and inhibits energy transition
evidence: 440MW coal-fired power plant, circulating fluidized-bed technology, reported environmental impacts on local communities

title: China donates office equipment to Ministry of Education and Training of Vietnam
description: On January 26, 2011, Chinese Ambassador Sun Guoxiang donated 10 sets of office equipment to the Ministry of Education and Training of Vietnam. The office equipment is worth VND 19.25 million.
combined_text:
# Sector
GOVERNMENT AND CIVIL SOCIETY

# Title
China donates office equipment to Ministry of Education and Training of Vietnam

# Description
On January 26, 2011, Chinese Ambassador Sun Guoxiang donated 10 sets of office equipment to the Ministry of Education and Training of Vietnam. The office equipment is worth VND 19.25 million.
justification: Project involves donation of office equipment to education ministry, with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Office equipment donation to Ministry of Education and Training, no energy-related components

title: CDB provides $200 million loan to Vietcombank for unspecified purposes
description: On August 29, 2011, China Development Bank (CDB) and Vietcombank — a state-owned commercial bank in Vietnam — signed a $200 million loan agreement for unspecified purposes. The borrowing terms of the loan are unknown.
staff_comments: 1. Vietcombank is a state-owned commercial bank. It is majority-owned (74.8% equity stake) by the country’s central bank (State Bank of Vietnam).
combined_text:

justification: Loan with unspecified purposes cannot be classified as having environmental impact

title: Chinese Government provides in-kind assistance worth $5.5 million
description: On March 1, 2011, the Chinese Government and Palestinian National Authority (PNA) signed an agreement regarding the provision of in-kind assistance worth $5.5 million. It is unclear what type of in-kind assistance was offered and whether/when this commitment was implemented.
combined_text:

justification: In-kind assistance with unspecified purpose, likely social development given sector and recipient
evidence: Government and Civil Society sector, unspecified in-kind assistance to Palestinian National Authority

title: Chinese Government donates sugar, rice, cooking oil, and medicines for humanitarian relief
description: The Chinese Government provided a humanitarian aid package — including sugar, rice, cooking oil, and medicines — to Yemen in September 2011. The aid was intended to address the humanitarian crisis caused by armed conflict and resettlement of refugees in Yemen. These goods started to be given out to Yemenis in Oman in March 2012.
staff_comments: The monetary value of this aid package is unknown.
combined_text:
# Sector
EMERGENCY RESPONSE

# Title
Chinese Government donates sugar, rice, cooking oil, and medicines for humanitarian relief

# Description
The Chinese Government provided a humanitarian aid package — including sugar, rice, cooking oil, and medicines — to Yemen in September 2011. The aid was intended to address the humanitarian crisis caused by armed conflict and resettlement of refugees in Yemen. These goods started to be given out to Yemenis in Oman in March 2012.
justification: Humanitarian aid package focused on basic necessities without direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Provision of food items (sugar, rice, cooking oil) and medicines for humanitarian relief

title: Chinese Government donates medical equipment, medicine, and clothing to northern Yemen
description: On April 18, 2011, the Chinese Ambassador to Yemen and the Yemeni Minister of Public Health signed a handover certificate for humanitarian aid for victims of the war in Sa'ada in northern Yemen. The aid package included medical equipment, medicine, and clothing. This project was completed.
staff_comments: The monetary value of this aid package is unknown.
combined_text:
# Sector
EMERGENCY RESPONSE

# Title
Chinese Government donates medical equipment, medicine, and clothing to northern Yemen

# Description
On April 18, 2011, the Chinese Ambassador to Yemen and the Yemeni Minister of Public Health signed a handover certificate for humanitarian aid for victims of the war in Sa'ada in northern Yemen. The aid package included medical equipment, medicine, and clothing. This project was completed.
justification: Humanitarian aid project focused on medical supplies and clothing without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Medical equipment, medicine, and clothing for war victims, humanitarian focus

title: Chinese Government funds establishment of Eye Center at Republican Hospital in Sana'a (Linked to Project ID#66322)
description: On January 17, 2011, the Chinese Government inaugurated an Eye (Ophthalmology) Center at the Republican Hospital (هيئة المستشفى الجمهوري التعليمي في صنعاء) in the capital city of Sana'a. The center performs free cataract surgeries for Yemenis and hosts Chinese ophthalmologists. The Secretary of the Party Leadership Group of the Ministry of Health Zhang Mao and Yemeni Vice President Abla Hadi attended the inauguration ceremony. At the ceremony, the Chinese government donated more than 2.8 million RMB worth of ophthalmic medical equipment including phacoemulsifiers and surgical microscopes to the Sana’a Republic Hospital, and will further cooperate with Yemen in personnel training and technical exchanges.  Previously, on January 15, 2011, 22 Yemeni patients with cataract were treated by the Chinese Ophthalmology Expert Team. The team for this free consultation was organized by the Health Department of Liaoning Province, China, and mainly came from the Jinzhou Yadong Eye Hospital (in Chinese: 辽宁省锦州亚东眼病医院) in Liaoning Province.  The Chinese side provided the center with advanced ophthalmic medical equipment and organized local doctors to go to China for training. In 2013, there were already 5 Yemeni doctors who studied in China working in the Eye Center, and they carried out free consultations with Chinese experts.
staff_comments: This project is also known as the Zhongye Ophthalmology Cooperation Center or China-Yemen Eye Cooperation Center. The Arabic project title is مركز التعاون الصينياليمني لطبوجراحةالعيون. The Chinese project title is 中也眼科中心 or 中也眼科合作中心.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
Chinese Government funds establishment of Eye Center at Republican Hospital in Sana'a (Linked to Project ID#66322)

# Description
On January 17, 2011, the Chinese Government inaugurated an Eye (Ophthalmology) Center at the Republican Hospital (هيئة المستشفى الجمهوري التعليمي في صنعاء) in the capital city of Sana'a. The center performs free cataract surgeries for Yemenis and hosts Chinese ophthalmologists. The Secretary of the Party Leadership Group of the Ministry of Health Zhang Mao and Yemeni Vice President Abla Hadi attended the inauguration ceremony. At the ceremony, the Chinese government donated more than 2.8 million RMB worth of ophthalmic medical equipment including phacoemulsifiers and surgical microscopes to the Sana’a Republic Hospital, and will further cooperate with Yemen in personnel training and technical exchanges.  Previously, on January 15, 2011, 22 Yemeni patients with cataract were treated by the Chinese Ophthalmology Expert Team. The team for this free consultation was organized by the Health Department of Liaoning Province, China, and mainly came from the Jinzhou Yadong Eye Hospital (in Chinese: 辽宁省锦州亚东眼病医院) in Liaoning Province.  The Chinese side provided the center with advanced ophthalmic medical equipment and organized local doctors to go to China for training. In 2013, there were already 5 Yemeni doctors who studied in China working in the Eye Center, and they carried out free consultations with Chinese experts.
justification: Project is focused on healthcare infrastructure and services with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Establishment of Eye Center, provision of medical equipment, personnel training, and free cataract surgeries

title: Chinese Government grants RMB 10 million for provision of medical equipment and supplies to Levy Mwanawasa Hospital
description: On December 29, 2011, the Chinese Government and Government Zambia signed 3 letters of exchange, one of which was for the provision of extra medical equipment and supplies to the Levy Mwanawasa General Hospital worth RMB 10 million. This donation was officially handed over to Zambian authorities on September 17, 2013.  The two other letters of exchange that were signed are captured in projects #15507 and #15518.
staff_comments: The Chinese project title is 援赞比亚卢萨卡综合医院提供医疗设备和医用物资事. It is unclear if these letters of exchange are related to the 2 Economic and Technical Cooperation Agreements (ETCAs) signed on December 12, 2011 — one for a grant and another for an interest-free loan.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
Chinese Government grants RMB 10 million for provision of medical equipment and supplies to Levy Mwanawasa Hospital

# Description
On December 29, 2011, the Chinese Government and Government Zambia signed 3 letters of exchange, one of which was for the provision of extra medical equipment and supplies to the Levy Mwanawasa General Hospital worth RMB 10 million. This donation was officially handed over to Zambian authorities on September 17, 2013.  The two other letters of exchange that were signed are captured in projects #15507 and #15518.
justification: Project focuses on healthcare provision without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Provision of medical equipment and supplies to hospital, healthcare sector focus

title: 16th medical team dispatched to Levy Mwanawasa Hospital, University of Zambia Teaching Hospital, Ndola General Hospital, Livingstone Central Hospital, and Kitwe Central Hospital
description: China has been sending medical teams to Zambia since 1978. Henan Province is responsible for sending the teams. The 16th medical team included 28 members who were stationed at Levy Mwanawasa Hospital, University of Zambia Teaching Hospital (also known as University Teaching Hospital), Ndola General Hospital, Livingstone Central Hospital, and Kitwe Central Hospital. The specialists on the team included physicians, gynecologists, surgeons, radiologists and dentists. The team began its term of service on November 26, 2011 and was expected to complete their work in late 2013.
staff_comments: In 2009, the Chinese Government provided a grant for the construction of the Levy Mwanawasa Hospital (project #32627). The 16th Chinese medical team was the first Chinese medical team to be stationed at Levy Mwanawasa Hospital.The Chinese medical teams have been dispatched to Zambia since 1978 and should not be confused with Chinese military medical teams, which have also been dispatched to Zambia. The Chinese military medical teams have been dispatched by the People's Liberation Army and not by Henan Province.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
16th medical team dispatched to Levy Mwanawasa Hospital, University of Zambia Teaching Hospital, Ndola General Hospital, Livingstone Central Hospital, and Kitwe Central Hospital

# Description
China has been sending medical teams to Zambia since 1978. Henan Province is responsible for sending the teams. The 16th medical team included 28 members who were stationed at Levy Mwanawasa Hospital, University of Zambia Teaching Hospital (also known as University Teaching Hospital), Ndola General Hospital, Livingstone Central Hospital, and Kitwe Central Hospital. The specialists on the team included physicians, gynecologists, surgeons, radiologists and dentists. The team began its term of service on November 26, 2011 and was expected to complete their work in late 2013.
justification: Project focuses on healthcare provision through medical teams, with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Medical team deployment to multiple hospitals, focus on healthcare services

title: Chinese Government donates batch of anti-malarial supplies worth 1.5 billion Kwacha
description: On December 29, 2011, the Chinese Government and the Government Zambia signed three letters of exchange, one of which was for the donation of a batch of anti-malarial supplies worth 1.5 billion kwacha to Chainama Hills College Hospital. This batch of anti-malarial supplies was officially delivered and handed over to the authorities on September 17, 2013.   The two other letters of exchange that were signed are captured in projects #2337 and #15518.
